Knowledge Point: Moloko, an SVO language, has head initial noun phrases. (\ref{ex:5:1}--\ref{ex:5:4}) show a few examples of noun phrases. A noun (nafat ‘day’ and ləhe ‘bush’ in \ref{ex:5:1}), multiple nouns (war elé háy ‘millet grain’ in \ref{ex:5:3} and war dalay ‘girl’ in \ref{ex:5:4}) or free pronoun (ne {\oneS} \ref{ex:5:2}) is the head of the NP. In the examples in this chapter, the noun phrases are delimited by square brackets.\footnote{The first line in each example is the orthographic form. The second is the phonetic form (slow speech) with morpheme breaks.}
Content 1: \gsrc [Nafat enen] anday atalay a [ləhe]. | \gll [nafat ɛnɛŋ] a-ndaj a-tal-aj a [lɪhɛ] | \gls day another \SSS-PRG \SSS-walk-CL at bush | \glt ‘One day, he was walking in the bush.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc [Nafat enen] anday atalay a [ləhe]. | \gll [nafat ɛnɛŋ] a-ndaj a-tal-aj a [lɪhɛ] | \gls day another \SSS-PRG \SSS-walk-CL at bush | \glt ‘One day, he was walking in the bush.’
Content 4: \gsrc Cəcəngehe na, [war elé háy bəlen] na, ásak asabay. | \gll tʃɪtʃɪŋgɛhɛ na [war ɛlɛ haj bɪlɛŋ] na á-sak asa-baj | \gls now PSP child eye millet one PSP \SSS+IFV-multiply again-NEG | \glt ‘And now, one grain of millet, it doesn’t multiply anymore.’
Content 6: \gsrc [Ne ahan] aməgəye. | \gll [nɛ =ahaŋ] amɪ-g-ijɛ | \gls oneS =\SSS.POSS DEP-do-CL | \glt ‘It was me (emphatic) that did it.’

Knowledge Point: A noun modified by the plural marker (\ref{ex:5:5}--\ref{ex:5:6}) (see \sectref{sec:4.2.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc N\'{ə}mənjar [awak \textbf{ahay}]. | \gll n\'{ə}-mənzar [awak\textbf{=ahaj}] | \gls oneS+IFV-see goat=Pl | \glt ‘I see goats.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Awak\textbf{ ahay} na ], [səlom \textbf{ahay} ga]. | \gll [awak\textbf{=ahaj} na] [sʊlɔm\textbf{=ahaj} ga] | \gls goat=Pl PSP good=Pl ADJ | \glt ‘The goats [are] good.’

Knowledge Point: A noun modified by a possessive pronoun (\ref{ex:5:7}--\ref{ex:5:8}) (see \sectref{sec:3.1.2}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc [Awak \textbf{əwla} na], [səlom ga]. | \gll [awak\textbf{=uwla} na] [sʊlɔm ga] | \gls goat=oneS.POSS PSP good ADJ | \glt ‘My goat [is] good.’

Knowledge Point: A noun modified by an unspecified pronoun (\ref{ex:5:9}--\ref{ex:5:10}) (see \sectref{sec:3.1.5}).
Content 1: \gsrc N\'{ə}mənjar [awak \textbf{enen}]. | \gll n\'{ə}-mənzar [awak \textbf{ɛnɛŋ}] | \gls oneS+IFV-see goat another | \glt ‘I see another goat.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Awak \textbf{enen} ahay na], [səlom ahay ga]. | \gll [awak \textbf{ɛnɛŋ}=ahaj na] [sʊlɔm=ahaj ga] | \gls goat other=Pl PSP good=Pl ADJ | \glt ‘Other goats [are] good.’

Knowledge Point: A noun modified by a numeral (\ref{ex:5:11}--\ref{ex:5:12}) (see \sectref{sec:3.3}).

Knowledge Point: A noun modified by a derived adjective (\ref{ex:5:13}--\ref{ex:5:14}) (see \sectref{sec:5.3}).
Content 1: \gsrc N\'{ə}mənjar [awak ahay \textbf{malan ahay ga}]. | \gll n\'{ə}-mənzar [awak=ahaj \textbf{malaŋ}\textbf{=ahaj} \textbf{ga}] | \gls oneS+IFV-see goat=Pl great=Pl ADJ | \glt ‘I see the big goats.’

Content 1: \gsrc N\'{ə}mənjar [awak ahay \textbf{gam}]. | \gll n\'{ə}-mənzar [awak=ahaj \textbf{gam}] | \gls oneS+IFV-see goat=Pl many | \glt ‘I see many goats.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Awak ahay \textbf{gam} na], [səlom ahay ga]. | \gll [awak=ahaj \textbf{gam} na] [sʊlɔm=ahaj ga] | \gls goat=Pl many PSP good=Pl ADJ | \glt ‘Many goats [are] good.’

Knowledge Point: A noun modified by a numeral and the adjectiviser ga (\ref{ex:5:21}--\ref{ex:5:22}).
Content 1: \gsrc N\'{ə}mənjar [awak ahay məfaɗ \textbf{ga}]. | \gll n\'{ə}-mənzar [awak=ahaj mʊfaɗ \textbf{ga}] | \gls oneS+IFV-see goat=Pl four ADJ | \glt ‘I see the four goats.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Awak ahay məfaɗ \textbf{ga}], [səlom ahay ga]. | \gll [awak=ahaj mʊfaɗ \textbf{ga}] [sʊlɔm=ahaj ga] | \gls goat=Pl four ADJ good=Pl ADJ | \glt ‘The four goats [are] good.’

Knowledge Point: The constituent order is shown in \figref{fig:8}, followed by illustrative examples (\ref{ex:5:23}--\ref{ex:5:30}). Not all constituents can co-occur in the same clause. There are restrictions on how complex a noun phrase can normally become. Restrictions include the fact that that quantifiers cannot co-occur in the same noun phrase as either derived adjectives or numerals. The order of relative clause and demonstrative does not appear to be strict. Note that nominal demonstratives are in a different position than local adverbial demonstratives.
Content 1: \gsrc N\'{ə}mənjar [awak əwla ahay]. | \gll n\'{ə}-mənzar [awak=uwla=ahaj] | \gls oneS+IFV-see goat=oneS.POSS=Pl | \glt ‘I see my goats.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Awak ahay ngəndəye jəyga na], [səlom ahay ga]. | \gll [awak=ahaj ŋgɪndijɛ dʒijga na] [sʊlɔm=ahaj ga] | \gls goat=Pl DEM all PSP good=Pl ADJ | \glt ‘All of those goats [are] good.’

Knowledge Point: Modification by possessive pronoun and plural marker (\ref{ex:5:23}--\ref{ex:5:24}).

Content 2: \gsrc [Awak əwla ahay na], [səlom ahay ga]. | \gll [awak=uwla=ahaj na] [sʊlɔm=ahaj ga] | \gls goat=oneS.POSS=Pl PSP good=Pl ADJ | \glt ‘My goats [are] good.’

Content 2: \gsrc [Awak əwla ahay [nok aməvəlaw] ngəndəye na], [səlom ahay ga]. | \gll [awak=uwla=ahaj [nɔkʷ amə-vəl=aw] ŋgɪndijɛ na] [sʊlɔm=ahaj ga] | \gls goat=oneS.POSS=Pl twoS DEP-give=oneS.IO DEM PSP good=Pl ADJ | \glt ‘Those goats of mine that you gave me [are] good.’

Knowledge Point: Noun phrases can have a head that is either a simple noun \REF{ex:5:31}, nominalised verb (\ref{ex:5:32}, \sectref{sec:5.2.1}), or a pronoun (\ref{ex:5:33}, \sectref{sec:5.2.2}). In the examples, the noun phrases are delimited by square brackets and the head is bolded.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc [\textbf{Məzəme} əwla] amanday acəɓan ana Mana. | \gll [\textbf{mɪ-ʒum-ɛ}=uwla] ama-ndaj a-tsəɓ=aŋ ana Mana | \gls NOM-eat-CL=oneS.POSS DEP-PROG 3S-overwhelm=3S.IO DAT Mana | \glt ‘[The act of] my eating is irritating Mana.’
Content 3: \gsrc [\textbf{Ndahan} ga] ánday áwas. | \gll [\textbf{ndahaŋ} ga] á-ndaj á-was | \gls 3S ADJ 3S+IFV-PROG 3S+IFV-cultivate | \glt ‘He himself is cultivating.’

Subsection: Noun phrases with nominalised verb heads\label{sec:5.2.1
Knowledge Point: When the head noun is a nominalised verb, the other elements in the noun phrase represent clausal arguments of the nominalised verb. The modifying noun represents the direct object Theme of the nominalised verb and the possessive pronoun or noun in a modifying genitive construction represents the subject of the verb. In \REF{ex:5:34}, the noun modifier ɗaf ‘millet loaf’ represents the direct object of the nominalised verb məzəme ‘eating’ and the \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{p} possessive pronoun ata represents the subject of the nominalised verb, i.e., ‘they are eating millet loaf.’
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Noun phrases with nominalised verb heads\label{sec:5.2.1
Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:5:35}, məndəye ango literally ‘your lying down’ indicates that ‘you are lying.’ The possessive pronoun ango is the subject of the nominalised verb məndəye. In \REF{ex:5:36}, both subject and direct object of the nominalised verb are present. Mana, the noun in the genitive construction (see \sectref{sec:5.4.1}) codes the subject of the nominalised verb and the ‘body-part’ verbal extension va is the direct object, i.e., ‘Mana is resting his body.’
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc  [membese va a Mana] | \gll [mɛ-mbɛʃ-ɛ va a Mana] | \gls \NOM-rest-CL body GEN Mana | \glt ‘Mana’s rest’ (lit. resting body of Mana)

Knowledge Point: A free pronoun head is more limited in the number of modifiers that it can take than a lexical noun head. A pronoun head can only be modified by the adjectiviser (\ref{ex:5:37}--\ref{ex:5:38}) or possessive pronoun in emphatic situations (\ref{ex:5:39}--\ref{ex:5:40}) (see \sectref{sec:3.1.1.2}). Noun phrases with pronoun heads can not be modified by plural, number, demonstrative, adjective, or relative clause.\footnote{Pronouns can be the subject of a relative clause, see \REF{ex:5:17} and \sectref{sec:5.4.3}.} The pronoun heads are bolded in the examples.
Content 1: \gsrc [\textbf{Ndahan ga}] [aməgəye]. | \gll [\textbf{ndahaŋ} \textbf{ga}] [amɪ-g-ijɛ] | \gls 3S ADJ DEP-do-CL | \glt ‘He is the one that did it.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Amədəye elele nəndəye na], [\textbf{ne ga}]. | \gll [amɪ-d-ijɛ ɛlɛlɛ nɪndijɛ na] [\textbf{nɛ} \textbf{ga}] | \gls DEP-prepare-CL sauce DEM PSP oneS ADJ | \glt ‘The one that prepared the sauce there [was] me.’
Content 3: \gsrc [\textbf{Ne ahan}] [aməgəye]. | \gll [\textbf{nɛ}\textbf{=ahaŋ}] [amɪ-g-ijɛ] | \gls oneS=3S.POSS DEP-do-CL | \glt ‘I myself [am] the one that did it.’
Content 4: \gsrc [\textbf{Ne ahan}] nólo a kosoko ava. | \gll [\textbf{nɛ}\textbf{=ahaŋ}] n\'{ɔ}-lɔ a kɔsɔkʷɔ ava | \gls oneS=3S.POSS oneS+IFV-go at market in | \glt ‘I myself am going to the market.’
Content 5: \gsrc N\'{ə}mənjar [awak əwla ahay makar [\textbf{nok aməvəlaw}].] | \gll n\'{ə}-mənzar [awak=uwla=ahaj makar [\textbf{nɔkʷ} \textbf{amə-vəl=aw}]] | \gls oneS+IFV-see goat=oneS.POSS=Pl three twoS DEP-give=oneS.IO | \glt ‘I see my three goats that you gave to me.’

Subsection: Structure of noun phrase containing ga
Knowledge Point: We consider that the adjectiviser is a separate phonological word with semantic scope over the preceding noun phrase.\footnote{\citet{Bow1997c} called this morpheme a noun affix. Also, for simple adjectivised noun constructions, speakers consider the adjectiviser to be part of the same word as the noun that is modified. However, in the absence of evidence for phonological bondedness, we consider ga to be a separate phonological word.} The adjectiviser maintains its position at the right edge of a noun phrase regardless of the noun phrase components (\ref{ex:5:44}--\ref{ex:5:49}). This fact indicates that it might be a clitic. However, we find no undisputable evidence that it is phonologically bound to the noun. Example \REF{ex:5:42} shows noun-final changes /n/ → [ŋ] before ga. These changes might be due to assimilation of /n/ to point of articulation of /g/ within a word (see \sectref{sec:2.2}). However, the same change would occur at a word break, with word-final changes to /n/ (see \sectref{sec:2.2.4} and \sectref{sec:2.6.1.2}).\footnote{We have not no examples of word-final alterations of /h/ before ga.} Also, the prosody of ga does not neutralise any prosody on the word to which it is bound.
Content 1: \gsrc Tákəwala [kəra mətece elé \textbf{ga.}] | \gll tá-kuw=ala [kəra mɪ-tɛtʃ-ɛ ɛlɛ \textbf{ga}] | \gls 3P+IFV-seek=to dog NOM-close-CL eye ADJ | \glt ‘They look for a puppy that hasn’t opened its eyes yet.’ (lit. a dog closing eyes)
Content 2: Not found

Subsection: Structure of noun phrase containing ga
Knowledge Point: When the head noun in a phrase that contains the adjectiviser ga is pluralised, both the head noun and the noun modifier are pluralised as well. Compare the singular noun phrase in \REF{ex:5:46} with the pluralised noun phrase in \REF{ex:5:47} where both the head noun and adjective are pluralised. %%\is{Plurality!Noun phrase plural}
Content 1: \gsrc Naharalay [awak babəɗ \textbf{ga}] a mogom. | \gll nà-har=alaj [awak babəɗ \textbf{ga}] a mɔgʷɔm | \gls oneS+PFV-carry=away goat white ADJ at home | \glt ‘I carried the white goat home.’
Content 2: \gsrc Naharala [awak ahay babəɗ ahay \textbf{ga}] a mogom. | \gll nà-har=alaj [awak=ahaj babəɗ=ahaj \textbf{ga}] a mɔgʷɔm | \gls oneS+PFV-carry=away goat=Pl white=Pl ADJ at home | \glt ‘I carried the white goats home.’

Subsection: Structure of noun phrase containing ga
Knowledge Point: The same pattern of pluralisation is shown in (\ref{ex:5:48}--\ref{ex:5:49}). Note that the plural is not becoming individually ‘adjectivised.’ but rather the entire noun phrase is adjectivised. Note also that the adjectiviser always maintains its position at the right edge of the noun phrase.
Content 1: \gsrc [Məze ahay səlom ahay \textbf{ga} na], tázala təta bay. | \gll [mɪʒɛ=ahaj sʊlɔm=ahaj \textbf{ga} na] tá-z=ala təta baj | \gls person=Pl good=Pl ADJ PSP 3P+IFV-take=to ability NEG | \glt ‘Good people (lit. people with the quality of goodness), they can’t bring [it].'
Content 2: Not found

Subsection: Functions of noun phrases containing ga
Knowledge Point: The morpheme ga has two other functions besides adjectiviser.\footnote{These two functions for ga do not indicate homophones. We interpret all cases of ga as the same morpheme since all instances pattern in exactly the same way even when their function is different. We conclude that the same morpheme is functioning at the noun phrase level as an adjectiviser and at the discourse level in definiteness and emphasis.} Ga can also function as a discourse demonstrative\is{Deixis!Demonstrative function of ga|(} to make the noun definite\is{Focus and prominence!Definiteness} and even sometimes emphatic. Its function to render a pronoun emphatic is discussed in \sectref{sec:3.1.1.2}. A set of examples from the Cicada story illustrates the discourse function. Examples (\ref{ex:5:52}--\ref{ex:5:54}) are from lines 5, 12 and 18 respectively (the Cicada story is found in its entirety in \sectref{sec:1.6}). The first mention in the narrative of agwazla ‘tree of a particular species’ is shown in \REF{ex:5:52}. The tree is introduced as agwazla malan ga ‘a large tree.’ Later on in the narrative, the particular tree that was found is mentioned again (\ref{ex:5:53} and \ref{ex:5:54}). In these occurrences however, the tree is not modified by an adjective, but the noun is simply marked by ga (agwazla ga ‘this tree of a particular species’ in \ref{ex:5:53} and memele ga ‘the tree’ in \ref{ex:5:54}). In these last two examples, ga indicates that ‘tree’ is referring to the particular tree previously mentioned in the discourse.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Subsection: Functions of noun phrases containing ga
Knowledge Point: In another story about a reconciliation ceremony between two warring parties (the Moloko and the Mbuko), the ceremony requires the cutting in two of a puppy. Which side received which part was a key element to the outcome of the ceremony. In the text, the first mention of dəray ‘the head’ \REF{ex:5:55} is marked with ga -- it is an expected part of the narrative frame. When the outcome of the ceremony revealed that the Moloko got the head part (and so ‘won’ the contest) and the Mbuko received the hind parts, both are adjectivised: dəray ga ‘the head’ and mətenen ga ‘the hindparts’ \REF{ex:5:56}. Note that \REF{ex:5:56} consists of two predicate possessive verbless clauses (see \sectref{sec:10.1.2}), each with a predicate that is an adjectivised noun.
Content 1: \gsrc Asa ləme n\'{ə}gəsom na [dəray \textbf{ga}] na, [səlom ga]. | \gll asa lɪmɛ n\'{ə}-gʊs-ɔm na [dəraj \textbf{ga}] na [sʊlɔm ga] | \gls if 1PEX oneS+IFV-catch-1PEX 3S.DO head ADJ PSP goodness ADJ | \glt ‘If we got the head, [it would be] good.'
Content 2: \gsrc [Dəray \textbf{ga}] anga ləme [mətenen \textbf{ga}] anga Mboko ahay. | \gll [dəraj \textbf{ga}] aŋga lɪmɛ [mɪtɛnɛŋ \textbf{ga}] aŋga mbɔkʷɔ=ahaj | \gls head ADJ POSS 1PEX hindparts ADJ POSS Mbuko=Pl | \glt ‘The head [is] ours; the hindparts [are] the Mbuko's.’
Content 3: \gsrc [Dəray \textbf{ga}] anga ləme [mətenen \textbf{ga}] anga Mboko ahay. | \gll [dəraj \textbf{ga}] aŋga lɪmɛ [mɪtɛnɛŋ \textbf{ga}] aŋga mbɔkʷɔ=ahaj | \gls head ADJ POSS 1PEX hindparts ADJ POSS Mbuko=Pl | \glt ‘The head [is] ours; the hindparts [are] the Mbuko's.’

Subsection: Functions of noun phrases containing ga
Knowledge Point: Compare \REF{ex:5:57} and \REF{ex:5:58} (from lines 1 and 39, respectively of the Disobedient Girl story; shown in its entirety in \sectref{sec:1.5}). The noun bamba ‘story,’ when first mentioned in the introduction of the story \REF{ex:5:57} is not adjectivised. When the same noun is mentioned again in the conclusion \REF{ex:5:58}, it is adjectivised ma bamba ga ‘the story.’

Content 2: Not found

Subsection: Functions of noun phrases containing ga
Knowledge Point: In the Cows in the Field story (not illustrated in this work) ga is used to mark the five brothers (previously mentioned) whose field was damaged and who had to go to the police to resolve the problem (\ref{ex:5:59} and \ref{ex:5:60}), and the problem (ma ga ‘that word’) that developed when they couldn’t find justice (\ref{ex:5:61} and \ref{ex:5:62}).

Content 2: \gsrc Nəbohom ta alay ləme [zlom \textbf{ga}]. | \gll n\`{ə}-bɔh-ɔm ta=alaj lɪmɛ [ɮɔm \textbf{ga}] | \gls oneSPEX+PFV-pour-1PEX 3P.DO=away 1PEX five ADJ | \glt ‘We gave them [our identity cards], we [were] the five [whose fields were damaged].’
Content 3: \gsrc Sen a slam na ava nendəge na, nəmənjorom [ma \textbf{ga}]. | \gll ʃɛŋ a ɬam na ava nɛndɪgɛ na n\`{ə}-mʊnzɔr-ɔm [ma \textbf{ga}] | \gls IDwalk at place PSP in DEM PSP oneS+PFV-see-1PEX word ADJ | \glt ‘Walking (later), at that place, we saw the problem.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nəbohom [ma \textbf{ga}] a brəygad ava. | \gll n\`{ə}-bɔh-ɔm [ma \textbf{ga}] a brijgad ava | \gls oneSPEX+PFV-pour-1PEX word ADJ at Brigade in | \glt ‘We took the problem to the Brigade.’

Subsection: Functions of noun phrases containing ga
Knowledge Point: The emphatic function of ga\footnote{The emphatic function of ga is discussed with respect to pronouns in \sectref{sec:3.1.1.2}.} mentioned above is even more obvious in the Values exhortation (see \sectref{sec:1.7}). Line 7 in the Values exhortation, shown in \REF{ex:5:63}, alludes to the commandments that Hərmbəlom awacala kə okor aka ‘God wrote on the stone,’ and line 12 \REF{ex:5:64} exhorts the hearer kóogəsok ma Hərmbəlom ‘you should accept the word of God.’ Further in the text, the mention of anga Hərmbəlom ga ‘the very [word] of God himself’ (\ref{ex:5:65} from line 28) draws attention to the fact that the people don’t accept what God himself wrote on the stone tablets. This time, the marker ga has an emphatic function.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \item Genitive construction. A head noun followed by a genitive noun phrase with the genitive particle a (\ref{ex:5:66}) (see \sectref{sec:5.4.1}).
Content 1: \gsrc [war [a bahay]] | \gll [war [a bahaj]] | \gls child GEN chief | \glt ‘the chief’s child’

Knowledge Point: \item Permanent attribution construction. Two nouns are juxtaposed with no intervening particle (\ref{ex:5:67}) (see \sectref{sec:5.4.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc [zar Məloko] | \gll [zar mʊlɔkʷɔ] | \gls man Moloko | \glt ‘Moloko man’

Knowledge Point: \item Relative clause (\ref{ex:5:68}) (see \sectref{sec:5.4.3}).
Content 1: \gsrc [war [aməgəye cəɗoy] akaray zana aloko apazan. | \gll [war [amɪ-g-ijɛ tsʊɗoj] à-kar-aj zana=alɔkʷɔ apazaŋ | \gls child DEP-do-CL wickedness 3S+PFV-steal-CL clothes=1PIN yesterday | \glt ‘The child that did wickedness stole our clothes yesterday.’

Knowledge Point: The genitive construction follows the head noun in a noun phrase. The genitive noun phrase consists of the genitive particle a plus a noun phrase expressing the possessor (\ref{ex:5:69} and \ref{ex:5:70}).
Content 1: \gsrc [zar [a Hawa]] | \gll [zar [a Hawa]] | \gls man GEN Hawa | \glt ‘Hawa’s husband’
Content 2: \gsrc [hay [a baba ango]] | \gll [haj [a baba=aŋgʷɔ]] | \gls house GEN father=twoS.POSS | \glt ‘your father’s house’

Knowledge Point: \citet{Bow1997c} remarks that the particle a appears to carry the tone HL, with a floating L.\footnote{Note that the genitive particle a and the adposition a (Sections \ref{sec:5.6.1} and \ref{sec:5.6.2}) are homophones.} She demonstrates in \REF{ex:5:71} that the floating low tone lowers the high tone of the noun (háy) to become M.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: \largerpage In a genitive construction, the relationship of the genitive noun phrase to the head noun is a temporary attribute of or relationship to the head.\footnote{As compared with the permanent attribution construction \sectref{sec:5.4.2}.} The semantic relationship between head noun and genitive expresses the same range of semantic notions as the possessive pronoun (see \sectref{sec:3.1.2.1}). In the examples below, the genitive construction expresses ownership (both alienable and inalienable, \ref{ex:5:72}), kinship \REF{ex:5:73}, partitive \REF{ex:5:74}, and other looser associations (\ref{ex:5:75}--\ref{ex:5:77}). When applicable, a corresponding pronominal possessive construction is also given for comparison.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: There are several idioms or figurative expressions in Moloko which involve genitive constructions where the head noun in the noun phrase is a body part such as ma ‘mouth’ (\ref{ex:5:78}--\ref{ex:5:80}) or hoɗ ‘stomach’ \REF{ex:5:81}.
Content 1: \gsrc [ma [a gəver]] | \gll [ma [a gɪvɛr]] | \gls mouth GEN liver | \glt ‘gall bladder’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc Ne a [hoɗ [a zazay]] ava. | \gll nɛ a [hʷɔɗ [a zazaj]] ava | \gls oneS at stomach GEN peace in | \glt ‘I [am] very peaceful.’ (lit. I, in the centre of peace)

Knowledge Point: All other modifiers in a genitive construction will modify the genitive noun and not the head noun. In \REF{ex:5:82}, the possessive modifies the genitive noun (my wife) and not the head noun (i.e., not ‘my bride price’). Likewise in \REF{ex:5:83}, the demonstrative modifies the genitive noun (‘this woman’) and not the head noun (i.e., not ‘this bride price’). In \REF{ex:5:84}, it is the genitive noun ‘animals’ that is pluralised and modified by ‘all’, not the head noun ‘chief.’
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In a ‘permanent attribution construction,’ the noun phrase has a head composed of two (or even three) nouns, which acts as a unit within a larger noun phrase (\ref{ex:5:85}--\ref{ex:5:91}). The nouns in a permanent attribution construction do not comprise a compound made of phonologically bound words, but are separate words (prosodies do not spread from one noun to the other, \REF{ex:5:87}, \REF{ex:5:88}, \REF{ex:5:91}, and there are word-final changes in the first noun). Semantically, the second noun in the noun phrase indicates something about the identity of the first noun or gives a permanent attribute of the head noun.\footnote{As compared with the genitive construction which gives a more temporary attribute \sectref{sec:5.4.1}.} The glosses in each of the examples below confirm this observation.
Content 1: \gsrc [zar Ftak] | \gll [zar Ftak] | \gls man Ftak | \glt ‘a man who was born in Ftak’
Content 2: \gsrc [zar slərele] | \gll [zar ɬɪrɛlɛ] | \gls man work | \glt ‘a man who is known as someone who works hard’
Content 3: \gsrc [zar jəgwer] | \gll [zar dʒɪgʷɛr] | \gls man shepherd | \glt ‘a shepherd’ (paid for his work)
Content 4: \gsrc [zar səlom] | \gll [zar sʊlɔm] | \gls man goodness | \glt ‘a man who is known for his goodness’
Content 5: \gsrc [zar slərele] | \gll [zar ɬɪrɛlɛ] | \gls man work | \glt ‘a man who is known as someone who works hard’

Knowledge Point: In a noun phrase with the permanent attribution construction as its head noun, other elements in the noun phrase modify the entire head (and not just one of the nouns in the construction, as is the case for the genitive construction, see \sectref{sec:5.4.1}). In \REF{ex:5:92}, the plural and the numeral modify the head noun ndam slərele and the sense is ‘his three workmen,’ not ‘the man of his three works.’ In \REF{ex:5:93}, the noun phrase has a triple noun head, war elé háy ‘millet grain.’ In this noun phrase, the derived adjective bəlen ga ‘one,’ the demonstrative nendəye ‘that,’ and the relative clause nok ameze ‘the one that you brought’ all modify the triple noun head war elé háy ‘millet grain.’ They do not just modify the noun war ‘child’ or háy ‘millet.’ In the examples below, the noun phrase is delimited by square brackets and the permanent attribution construction is bolded.
Content 1: \gsrc [\textbf{ndam slərele} ahan ahay makar]. | \gll [\textbf{ndam} \textbf{ɬɪrɛlɛ}=ahaŋ=ahaj makar] | \gls people work=3S.POSS=Pl three | \glt ‘his three workmen’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: It is interesting that when dependent and nominalised clauses (see \sectref{sec:7.6} and \sectref{sec:7.7}) are within permanent attribution and genitive constructions, the same modal differences seen in \sectref{sec:12.1.1} still apply. The nominalised form of the verb functions to give a particular situation a finished idea, with an event that has been accomplished before the point of reference, almost as a state. In contrast, the dependent form of the verb is employed in situations which have an incomplete idea, one that is not yet achieved. Compare \REF{ex:5:94} and \REF{ex:5:95}. Example \REF{ex:5:94} refers to someone whose identity is a shepherd\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Mood in noun phrase} -- he is a man who makes his living caring for sheep or other animals. He probably is hired. This more permanent identity or state is expressed through the nominalised form of the verb in a permanent attribution construction. In contrast, \REF{ex:5:95} (a relative clause, see \sectref{sec:5.4.3}) reflects a man who cares for sheep but being a shepherd isn’t his identity -- he has sheep now but may not always have them. It is an incomplete or not completely realised situation expressed through the dependent form of the verb (a relative clause, but similar to the genitive).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc məze aməjəgwere təmak | \gll mɪʒɛ amɪ-dʒɪgʷɛr-ɛ təmak | \gls person DEP-shepherd-CL sheep | \glt ‘a person that cares for sheep’ (lit. person to care for sheep)
Content 4: \gsrc məze aməjəgwere təmak | \gll mɪʒɛ amɪ-dʒɪgʷɛr-ɛ təmak | \gls person DEP-shepherd-CL sheep | \glt ‘a person that cares for sheep’ (lit. person to care for sheep)

Knowledge Point: Likewise, compare \REF{ex:5:96} and \REF{ex:5:97}. In \REF{ex:5:96}, the dependent verb form is used to give the idea that the person has stolen something from someone, perhaps only once in his life (a non-permanent attribution). In contrast, the permanent attribution construction in \REF{ex:5:97}\footnote{Akar is the irregular nominalised form of the verb karay (see \sectref{sec:4.2}).} expresses that the man is a thief by identity or occupation -- he steals to make his living. Another nominalised form is shown in \REF{ex:5:98} and the form məze məkəre ga ‘person thefted' expresses a completed event. In this case, use of the adjectivised form indicates that the noun phrase head məze ‘person' is the person who experienced the theft.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc zar akar | \gll zar akar | \gls man theft | \glt ‘a thief’ (lit. man thief)
Content 4: \gsrc zar akar | \gll zar akar | \gls man theft | \glt ‘a thief’ (lit. man thief)

Knowledge Point: The head noun of the relative clause can be either the subject or the direct object of the relative clause. When the head noun is the subject of the relative clause (\ref{ex:5:99}--\ref{ex:5:102}), there is a gap for subject in the relative clause (marked by Ø in the examples). For example, the understood subject of the relative clause in \REF{ex:5:99} is the same as war dalay ‘the girl’ in the noun phrase. In the example, the Ø is a zero marking where the subject of the clause would otherwise be. There is a gap for subject because the subject of the relative clause is the same as the head of the noun phrase that is being modified. The relative clause is bolded and the noun phrase is delimited by square brackets in the examples in this section.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Nde [ləbara əwla ga \textbf{amətaraləkwəye} \textbf{ma}] nehe. | \gll ndɛ [ləbara =uwla ga \textbf{Ø} \textbf{amə-tar}\textbf{=alʊkʷøjɛ} \textbf{ma}] nɛhɛ | \gls so news =oneS.POSS ADJ {  DEP-call=twoP.IO mouth DEM | \glt ‘So, this is my news that I have called you together (to hear).’ (lit. So, my news which called mouth to you [is] this here)

Knowledge Point: When the head noun is the direct object of the relative clause, the relative clause must contain a subject pronoun. The pronoun must be inserted before the verb in the relative clause (\ref{ex:5:103}--\ref{ex:5:105}). It is interesting that this subject pronoun of the relative clause is sometimes a free pronoun (\ref{ex:5:104}, \ref{ex:5:105}, \ref{ex:5:109}, see \sectref{sec:3.1.1}) but in other cases is a possessive pronoun (\ref{ex:5:103}, see \sectref{sec:3.1.2}). Two examples from the same narrative\footnote{The entire narrative is not included in this work.} (\ref{ex:5:103} and \ref{ex:5:104}) use different pronouns for the subject of the relative clause. While \REF{ex:5:103} uses the \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{p} possessive pronoun ata, \REF{ex:5:104} uses the free pronoun təta. In some cases, the relative clause will contain the direct object pronominal na following the dependent verb. The \DO pronominal represents the noun phrase head. In the examples below, the direct object pronominal na is underlined. A gap for the direct object in the relative clause (\ref{ex:5:104} and \ref{ex:5:109}) is indicated by {Ø}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tasan oko ana [hay \textbf{ata aməgəye na va}]. | \gll tà-s=aŋ ɔkʷɔ ana [haj\textbf{=atəta} \textbf{amɪ-g-ijɛ} \textbf{na}=\textbf{va}] | \gls 3P+PFV-cut=3S.IO fire DAT house=3P.POSS DEP-do-CL 3S.DO=PRF | \glt ‘They set fire to the house that the others had made.’
Content 2: \gsrc [War háy ngəndəye \textbf{nok ameze na va}] bəlen ngəndəye na, | \gll [war haj ŋgɪndijɛ \textbf{nɔkʷ} \textbf{amɛ-ʒ-ɛ} \textbf{na}\textbf{=va}] bɪlɛŋ ŋgɪndijɛ na | \gls child millet DEM twoS DEP-take-CL 3S.DO=PRF one DEM PSP | \glt ‘That grain that you have taken, that one [grain],’
Content 4: \gsrc [War háy ngəndəye \textbf{nok ameze na va}] bəlen ngəndəye na, | \gll [war haj ŋgɪndijɛ \textbf{nɔkʷ} \textbf{amɛ-ʒ-ɛ} \textbf{na}\textbf{=va}] bɪlɛŋ ŋgɪndijɛ na | \gls child millet DEM twoS DEP-take-CL 3S.DO=PRF one DEM PSP | \glt ‘That grain that you have taken, that one [grain],’
Content 6: \gsrc Tasan oko ana [hay \textbf{ata aməgəye na va}]. | \gll tà-s=aŋ ɔkʷɔ ana [haj\textbf{=atəta} \textbf{amɪ-g-ijɛ} \textbf{na}=\textbf{va}] | \gls 3P+PFV-cut=3S.IO fire DAT house=3P.POSS DEP-do-CL 3S.DO=PRF | \glt ‘They set fire to the house that the others had made.’
Content 7: \gsrc Tasan oko ana [hay \textbf{ata aməgəye na va}]. | \gll tà-s=aŋ ɔkʷɔ ana [haj\textbf{=atəta} \textbf{amɪ-g-ijɛ} \textbf{na}=\textbf{va}] | \gls 3P+PFV-cut=3S.IO fire DAT house=3P.POSS DEP-do-CL 3S.DO=PRF | \glt ‘They set fire to the house that the others had made.’
Content 9: \gsrc Tasan oko ana [hay \textbf{ata aməgəye na va}]. | \gll tà-s=aŋ ɔkʷɔ ana [haj\textbf{=atəta} \textbf{amɪ-g-ijɛ} \textbf{na}=\textbf{va}] | \gls 3P+PFV-cut=3S.IO fire DAT house=3P.POSS DEP-do-CL 3S.DO=PRF | \glt ‘They set fire to the house that the others had made.’

Knowledge Point: \REF{ex:5:106} is more complex since the subject of the relative clause includes the speaker along with the head of the noun phrase (məze enen ahay ‘some other people’). The relative clause begins with the \oldstylenums{1}\textsc{Pex} pronoun ləme. The speaker brought food to those people who helped him to drive the cows.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In all of the above examples, the head noun can be modified by other modifiers in addition to the relative clause. Sometimes, however, the relative clause itself is the entire noun phrase (\ref{ex:5:107}--\ref{ex:5:108}). These noun phrases that consist of relative clauses take no other noun phrase modifiers. Also, they are apparently limited in the type of clause construction in which they can occur. They can only be the predicate of a larger predicate nominal construction (see \sectref{sec:10.1.2}). Examples \REF{ex:5:107} and \REF{ex:5:108} are interrogative constructions with a predicate nominal structure (see \sectref{sec:10.3.1}). We found no natural examples where a headless relative clause served as a matrix component in a matrix verbal clause. Example \REF{ex:5:108} is an emphatic construction (see \sectref{sec:10.3.5}).
Content 1: \gsrc [\textbf{Aməzəɗe dəray na}] way? | \gll [\textbf{Ø} \textbf{amɪ-ʒɪɗ-ɛ} \textbf{dəraj} \textbf{na}] waj | \gls {  DEP-carry-CL head PSP who | \glt ‘Who will win?’ (lit. the one to carry the head, who?)
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc [\textbf{Aməzəɗe dəray na}] way? | \gll [\textbf{Ø} \textbf{amɪ-ʒɪɗ-ɛ} \textbf{dəraj} \textbf{na}] waj | \gls {  DEP-carry-CL head PSP who | \glt ‘Who will win?’ (lit. the one to carry the head, who?)

Knowledge Point: Noun phrases with relative clauses can get quite complicated in Moloko even though they only occur in specific places in discourse. In \REF{ex:5:109}, there are two relative clauses together, both modifying the head noun ɛlɛ ‘thing.’ In the first (ne amahan the thing ‘that I told her’) the head of the noun phrase corresponds to the direct object of the verb in the relative clause (marked as Ø in the example). In the second (aməjəye mege bay the thing ‘that I said she should not do’) there is an embedded complement clause within the relative clause (delimited by lines). In this second relative clause, the element that corresponds to the head of the noun phrase is represented by Ø within the complement clause.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Plural head nouns in noun phrases containing a relative clause have so far only been noted in elicited relative clauses and their interpretation is ambiguous. In these noun phrases, speakers insert the plural =ahay in one of two places: the plural =ahay can occur immediately following the head noun, or in some instances it may follow the relative clause. The plural precedes the relative clause in (\ref{ex:5:110}--\ref{ex:5:111}).
Content 1: \gsrc [Ele ahay \textbf{nok aməzəɗe na}], anga əwla bay. | \gll [ɛlɛ=ahaj \textbf{nɔkʷ} \textbf{amɪ-ʒɪɗ-ɛ} \textbf{na}] aŋga=uwla baj | \gls thing=Pl twoS DEP-take-CL PSP POSS=oneS.POSS NEG | \glt ‘The things that you brought [are] not belonging to me.’
Content 2: \gsrc [Məze ahay \textbf{aməzəɗe dəray na}], tolo a mogom nə memle ga. | \gll [mɪʒɛ=ahaj \textbf{amɪ-ʒɪɗ-ɛ} \textbf{dəraj} \textbf{na}] tɔ-lɔ a mɔgʷɔm nə mɛmlɛ ga | \gls person=Pl DEP-take-CL head PSP 3P-go at home with joy ADJ | \glt ‘The people that won went home with joy.’

Knowledge Point: When the plural =ahay occurs after the relative clause \REF{ex:5:113}, exactly what is pluralised is ambiguous. The relative clause follows a singular head noun in \REF{ex:5:112}. However, when the head noun is plural, the relative clause is sandwiched between the head noun and the plural marker \REF{ex:5:113}. In \REF{ex:5:113}, the possibilities are chief’s house/ chief’s houses / chiefs’ house / chiefs’ houses,’ depending on if ndam, hay, bahay, or all three are pluralised. Thus, when plural forms are used in Moloko discourse, which possibility is correct must be already clear from the context.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The end of the relative clause is sometimes delimited by the presupposition marker na (see \chapref{chap:11}). \REF{ex:5:99} is repeated here as \REF{ex:5:114} (see also \ref{ex:5:104}, \ref{ex:5:106}, \ref{ex:5:107}). Na indicates that the relative clause contains previously shared (or presupposed) information. Na also physically delineates the end of the relative clause. In \REF{ex:5:114}, the presupposition marker na is underlined.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 5: \gsrc [\textbf{Aməzəɗe dəray na}] way? | \gll [\textbf{Ø} \textbf{amɪ-ʒɪɗ-ɛ} \textbf{dəraj} \textbf{na}] waj | \gls {  DEP-carry-CL head PSP who | \glt ‘Who will win?’ (lit. the one to carry the head, who?)

Knowledge Point: Consider the Disobedient Girl text (see \sectref{sec:1.5} for the full narrative). The moral of the story is to instruct children (especially girls) to be obedient. There are relative clauses in S. 13 \REF{ex:5:115}, S. 29 \REF{ex:5:109}, S. 33 \REF{ex:5:101}, and S. 38 \REF{ex:5:114}. Note that all but one \REF{ex:5:115} of the relative clauses in this narrative concern the moral of the story. The Disobedient girl story involves suffering of a particular nature that was brought on by a particular girl who disobeyed specific instructions. The instructions that she disobeyed are in a relative clause within the husband’s lament when he finds her (\ref{ex:5:109}). The disobedient girl is the head of two relative clauses at the end of the story, one citing her as the reason that God got angry (\ref{ex:5:101}) and the other stating that she brought suffering to the Moloko people (\ref{ex:5:114}). The only relative clause that does not concern information relevant to the moral of the story \REF{ex:5:115} is from a section in the narrative where the man instructs his wife on how much millet to grind. The man tells her to take one grain of millet. Then he specifies with a relative clause ‘that one grain of millet you have taken.’ This relative clause specifies the one grain of millet (from the other grains in the sack) that will be multiplied for them.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Note that the relative clauses that contain information about the moral of the story are at the end of the narrative; there are no relative clauses related to the moral of the story at the beginning of the narrative -- the noun phrases in S.10--S.11 \REF{ex:5:116} that introduce her and identify her as disobedient contain no relative clause.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In the Snake narrative (see \sectref{sec:1.4}), there is only one relative clause. This relative clause shows another function of relative clauses in discourse. The relative clause, amədəvala okfom nehe ‘the thing that caused the mouse to fall’ in line 7 \REF{ex:5:108}, contains the first mention (albeit indirect) of the snake who is a central participant in the story and the reason that the story was told.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The basic way to coordinate two participants in Moloko is to join two noun phrases by the adposition nə ‘with’ (see \sectref{sec:5.6.1}). Modifiers will have semantic scope over both of the coordinated elements. In \REF{ex:5:117}--\REF{ex:5:119}, the noun phrases are delimited by square brackets and the adpositions are bolded.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc [[Zar] \textbf{nə} [hor ahan]] tolo a mehele ava. | \gll [[zar] \textbf{nə} [hʷɔr=ahaŋ]] tɔ-lɔ a mɛ-hɛl-ɛ ava | \gls man with woman=3S.POSS 3P-go at NOM-unite-CL in | \glt ‘A man and his wife went to the meeting.’

Knowledge Point: The preposition a ‘at’\footnote{This particle is a homophone with the genitive particle (\sectref{sec:5.4.1}). } marks the relationship of location\is{Deixis!Locational} of the event (at, to, in; \ref{ex:5:120}, \ref{ex:5:121}).
Content 1: \gsrc T\'{ə}nday t\'{ə}talay \textbf{a} ləhe. | \gll t\'{ə}-ndaj t\'{ə}-tal-aj \textbf{a} lɪhɛ | \gls 3P+IFV-PRG 3P+IFV-walk-CL at bush | \glt ‘They were walking in the bush.’
Content 2: \gsrc Olo \textbf{a} Marva. | \gll \`{ɔ}-lɔ \textbf{a} Marva | \gls 3S+PFV-go at Maroua | \glt ‘He/she went to Maroua.’

Knowledge Point: The adposition ana ‘to’ marks the indirect object which is the place where the action of the verb occurs; the recipient, benefactive, or malefactive (\ref{ex:5:122}, \ref{ex:5:123}, see \sectref{sec:9.2} for a discussion of semantic roles).
Content 1: \gsrc Tolo na, tasan oko \textbf{ana} hay ata aməgəye na va. | \gll tə-lɔ na ta-s=aŋ ɔkʷɔ \textbf{ana} haj=atəta amɪ-g-ijɛ na=va | \gls 3P-go PSP 3P-cut=3S.DO fire DAT house=3P.POSS DEP-do-CL 3S.DO=PRF | \glt ‘They went and set fire to the house that they had built.’
Content 2: \gsrc Adəkaka alay \textbf{ana} Hərmbəlom. | \gll a-dəkʷ=aka=alaj \textbf{ana} Hʊrmbʊlɔm | \gls 3S-arrive=on=away DAT God | \glt ‘It reached God.’

Knowledge Point: The adposition nə ‘with’ marks the instrument \REF{ex:5:124} or comitative (accompaniment) relation (\ref{ex:5:125}, \ref{ex:5:126}; cf. \sectref{sec:5.5}). The adposition is also used to form the verb focus construction (\ref{ex:5:127}, see \sectref{sec:7.6.3}).
Content 1: \gsrc Naslay sla \textbf{nə} mekec. | \gll na-ɬ-aj ɬa \textbf{nə} mɛkɛtʃ | \gls oneS-slay-CL cow with knife | \glt ‘I kill the cow with a knife.’
Content 2: \gsrc Olo \textbf{nə} zar ahan. | \gll ɔ-lɔ \textbf{nə} zar=ahaŋ | \gls 3S-go with man=3S.POSS | \glt ‘She went with her husband.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nəskom awak \textbf{nə} məskwəme. | \gll n\`{ə}-sʊkʷɔm awak \textbf{nə} mɪ-skʷøm-ɛ | \gls oneS+PFV-buy/sell goat with NOM-buy/sell-CL | \glt ‘I really bought the goat.’ (lit. I bought the goat with buying)

Knowledge Point: The adposition nə ‘with’ also participates in forming comparative constructions\is{Attribution!Comparative constructions} in Moloko. When one noun phrase is compared with another, it is done by means of a clause construction using the verb dal, ‘overtake.’\footnote{The verb dal ‘overtake’ takes subject prefixes and carries aspectual tone. Other constructions can be employed when comparing people \REF{ex:5:97} or ideas (line 49 in the Values exhortation).} The standard of comparison (baba =ahan ‘his father’ in \ref{ex:5:128} and \ref{ex:5:129}, and mədəga =ahan ‘his older sibling’ in \ref{ex:5:130}) is the direct object of the verb. The quality being compared (səber ‘tallness’ in \ref{ex:5:128}, gədan ‘strength’ in \ref{ex:5:129}, and məsəre ele ‘knowledge’ in \ref{ex:5:130}) follows in an adpositional phrase.
Content 1: \gsrc zar akar | \gll zar akar | \gls man theft | \glt ‘a thief’ (lit. man thief)
Content 2: \gsrc War ahan ádal baba ahan nə səber. | \gll war=ahaŋ á-dal baba=ahaŋ nə ʃɪbɛr | \gls child=3S.POSS 3S+IFV-overtake father=3S.POSS with tallness | \glt ‘The child is taller than his father.’ (lit. his child surpasses his father with tallness)
Content 3: \gsrc War ahan ádal baba ahan nə gədan. | \gll war=ahaŋ á-dal baba=ahaŋ nə gədaŋ | \gls child=3S.POSS 3S+IFV-overtake father=3S.POSS with strength | \glt ‘The child is stronger than his father.’
Content 5: \gsrc War ahan ádal baba ahan nə səber. | \gll war=ahaŋ á-dal baba=ahaŋ nə ʃɪbɛr | \gls child=3S.POSS 3S+IFV-overtake father=3S.POSS with tallness | \glt ‘The child is taller than his father.’ (lit. his child surpasses his father with tallness)
Content 6: \gsrc War ahan ádal baba ahan nə gədan. | \gll war=ahaŋ á-dal baba=ahaŋ nə gədaŋ | \gls child=3S.POSS 3S+IFV-overtake father=3S.POSS with strength | \glt ‘The child is stronger than his father.’

Knowledge Point: No ‘less than’ comparatives were found in the data. Superlative constructions are possible but are not used often in Moloko culture. \REF{ex:5:131} illustrates what people say in an elicitation context.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The adposition aka ‘on’ is used with the verb lo ‘go’ to mark the purpose of a trip \REF{ex:5:132}.
Content 1: \gsrc Aban olo \textbf{aka} yam. | \gll Abaŋ ɔ-lɔ \textbf{aka} jam | \gls Aban 3S-go on water | \glt ‘Aban goes to get water.’ (lit. she goes on water)

Knowledge Point: The adposition anga indicates possession. The predicate possessive construction is discussed in \sectref{sec:10.1.2}. In the possessive construction, anga indicates a possessive relationship between the noun in the adpositional phrase and the other noun phrase in the construction. In \REF{ex:5:133}, anga indicates that dəray ‘head’ is possessed by ləme ‘us.’
Content 1: \gsrc [Dəray ga] [\textbf{anga} ləme.] | \gll [dəraj ga] [\textbf{aŋga} lɪmɛ] | \gls head ADJ POSS 1PEX | \glt ‘We got the head.’ (lit. the head, belonging to us)

Knowledge Point: The adposition afa ‘at the house of’ plus a noun phrase gives a location\is{Deixis!Locational} at the house of the referent specified in the noun phrase \REF{ex:5:134}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nolo afa bahay. | \gll nʊ-lɔ afa bahaj | \gls oneS-go {at.house.of chief | \glt ‘I go to the chief’s house.’

Knowledge Point: The adposition ka ‘like’ introduces an adverbial complement that expresses manner. Ka appears twice in \REF{ex:5:135}. In the second instance, ka carries the directional extension ala ‘towards.’
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: There are two complex adpositional phrases, each composed of the combination of a preposition and a postposition that surround the noun phrase. The adpositions give locational\is{Deixis!Locational} information. The first, kə…aka ‘on’ marks the noun phrase as being a location to which the event expressed by the verb is directed. It can be employed in a physical sense (\ref{ex:5:136}--\ref{ex:5:138}) or a figurative sense \REF{ex:5:139}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Azaɗ oloko \textbf{kə} dəray a məwta \textbf{aka}. | \gll à-zaɗ ɔlɔkʷɔ \textbf{kə} dəraj a muwta \textbf{aka} | \gls 3S+PFV-carry wood on head GEN truck on | \glt ‘He/she carried the wood on top of the truck.’ (lit. on the head of the truck)
Content 3: \gsrc Hərmbəlom agə ɓərav va \textbf{ka} war anga məze dedelen ga \textbf{aka}. | \gll Hʊrmbʊlɔm a-gə ɓərav =va \textbf{ka} war aŋga mɪʒɛ dɛdɛlɛŋ ga \textbf{aka} | \gls God 3S-do heart =PRF on child POSS person black ADJ on | \glt ‘God was angry with the black man’s child.’ (lit. God did heart on the child that belongs to the black person)

Knowledge Point: The second complex adpositional phrase, a…ava ‘in,’ the preposition and postposition surround a noun phrase to mark that noun phrase as being a physical location in which the action of the verb is directed (\ref{ex:5:140} and \ref{ex:5:141}).
Content 1: \gsrc Olo \textbf{a} kosoko \textbf{ava}. | \gll ɔ-lɔ \textbf{a} kɔsɔkʷɔ \textbf{ava} | \gls 3S-go at market in | \glt ‘He/she goes to market.’
Content 2: \gsrc Afaɗ dala \textbf{a} ombolo \textbf{ava}. | \gll a-faɗ dala \textbf{a} ambɔlɔ \textbf{ava} | \gls 3S-put money at sack in | \glt ‘He/she put the money into [his] sack.’

Knowledge Point: The postpositions aka ‘on’ and ava ‘in’ have the same forms as the verb adpositional\is{Adpositionals} extensions =aka ‘on’ and =ava ‘in’ (see \sectref{sec:7.5.1}). The extensions permit the presence of the complex adpositional phrase which gives further precision concerning the location of the event (\ref{ex:5:142} and \ref{ex:5:143}\footnote{Even though the verb in this example has verbal extensions, it is not conjugated for subject since it is a climactic point in the story where nominalised forms are often found. This is discussed further in Sections \ref{sec:7.6} and \ref{sec:8.2.3}.}). In the examples, the postpositions and verbal extensions are both bolded.
Content 1: \gsrc Afəɗ\textbf{aka} war elé háy na \textbf{kə} ver \textbf{aka}. | \gll a-fəɗ=\textbf{aka} war ɛlɛ haj na \textbf{kə} vɛr \textbf{aka} | \gls 3S-place=on child eye millet PSP on stone on | \glt ‘She put the grain of millet on the grinding stone.’
Content 2: \gsrc Məmət\textbf{ava} alay \textbf{a} ver \textbf{ava}. | \gll mə-mət=\textbf{ava}=alaj \textbf{a} vɛr \textbf{ava} | \gls NOM-die=in=away at room in | \glt ‘She died in the room.’
